Hi guys, just started using ember-cordova and as part of the setup you need to change config.locationType to ‘hash’ in environment.js. Consequently this adds an extra #:id in my routes i.e. /:userid/#:userid which I don’t want. Anyone know how to get round this? Thanks

<@U09CS0TJ9> - that may or may not be a problem. If it runs on Cordova, the address bar won’t show, so that won’t matter. Now, if you have the same codebase running outside Cordova, and you want to avoid the hash, an option would be to have an envvar switching which `locationType` to use for each build
so `config.locationType = ‘hash’` in the Cordova build, conditional to an envvar
Thanks Pablo I thought about that, I’ll give that a go.

thats interesting, our cordova app has the hash but only at the start:
`<http://localhost:4200/#/account/>`
<@U3W7SH77W> - is the hash lost in other routes, or do routes exist on top of the hash?
its always there, all the routes exist on top
right. Then that’s the way it’s expected to work, when configured to use it
now that you mentioned, I hadn’t realised that Steve’s example had something relevant (`:userid`) before the hash. I’m confused now
yeah what he has looks odd
having another look.
<@U05485UQL> <@U3W7SH77W> this is what I’m getting: <https://www.collated.net/stevetyler_uk#/stevetyler_uk>

I’d be happy to have a look next Project Night
